bestBHT.bht: Let us pursue the things of peace and mutual edification, finding our exercise in our interactions with one another and in making allowances. The things of peace are those that make for a man's own peace in his own conscience distressed with sin, looking to and dealing with the blood of Christ that speaks peace and pardon. By practicing acts of charity and serving one another in love, we promote edification and contribute to the peace among us. Practical divinity, focused on love and service, leads to both peace and edification.

Henry Alford: 19.] Inference from the foregoing two verses, mutual edification, i.e. the work of edification, finding its exercise in our mutual intercourse and allowances.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: simply, "the things of peace, and the things of mutual
Albert Barnes: If men aim at the great objects proposed by the Christian religion, they will live in peace.
Christians have more things in which they 'agree' than in which they differ.
Christians are thus regarded... as one great temple erected for the glory of God, having no separate interest, but as united for one object.
Marvin Vincent: Things which make for peace [τα της ειρηνης] . Lit. the things of peace.
Lit., things of edification, that, namely, which is with reference to one another.
John Calvin: We must indeed eat, that we may live; we ought to live, that we may serve the Lord; and he serves the Lord, who by benevolence and kindness edifies his neighbor.
For wherever there is even a spark of godliness, there the work of God is to be seen; which they demolish, who by their unfeeling conduct disturb the conscience of the weak.
Though we eat not anything we please, but abstain from the use of meats for the sake of our brethren; yet the kingdom of God continues entire and complete.
Philip Schaff: Follow after the things of peace; those things which constitute peace.
And the things which pertain to mutual edification.
Build up, instead of pulling down, the work of God already begun in his heart.
Archibald T. Robertson: The things of edification for one another.
John Gill: The things which make for a man's own peace in his own conscience distressed with sin, are looking to, and dealing with the blood of Christ, which speaks peace and pardon.
Attending on ordinances, and exercising a conscience void of offence towards God and men, are means of continuing and promoting a man's peace.
Edification is promoted by deeds, by acts of charity, or love; for charity edifies not by bare words but by loving in deed and in truth, by serving one another in love.
John Wesley: Peace and edification are closely joined.
Practical divinity tends equally to peace and to edification.
Controversial divinity less directly tends to edification.

bhtAttempts.bht: Let us pursue the things of peace and mutual edification, finding our exercise in our interactions with one another and in making allowances. The things of peace are those that make for a man's own peace in his own conscience, looking to and dealing with the blood of Christ that speaks peace and pardon. As Christians, we are called to build up, rather than tear down, the work of God already begun in each other's hearts. By practicing acts of charity and serving one another in love, we promote edification and contribute to the peace among us. Practical divinity, focused on love and service, leads to both peace and edification.

Practical divinity, focused on love and service, leads to both peace and edification.

Let us pursue the things of peace and mutual edification, finding our exercise in practicing acts of charity and serving one another in love. The things of peace are those that make for a man's own peace in his own conscience, looking to and dealing with the blood of Christ that speaks peace and pardon. By promoting edification through love and service, we contribute to the peace among us. Practical divinity, focused on love and service, leads to both peace and edification.

In our pursuit of peace and mutual edification, we are called to practice acts of charity and serve one another in love. The things of peace refer to finding peace in our own conscience by looking to and dealing with the blood of Christ that brings peace and pardon. By promoting edification through acts of love, we contribute to the peace among us. Focusing on practical divinity, centered on love and service, leads to both peace and edification.
